{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{infobox ethnic group | group = Hyderabadi Muslims
| native_name = {{Lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|حیدرآبادی مسلمان}}|(Hyderābādi Musalmān)}} | image = File:Asaf Jah I.jpg|[[Asaf Jah I]] File:Mir osman ali khan.JPG|[[Osman Ali Khan, Asaf Jah VII]] File:Sania Mirza.jpg|[[Sania Mirza]] File:Shahrukh interacts with media after KKR's maiden IPL title.jpg|Shahrukh Khan | population = 925,929 (1881){{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lFgoAAAAYAAJ|title=Hyderabad (Deccan) Under Sir Salar Jung|last=Ali|first=Cherágh|date=1886-01-01|publisher=Printed at the Education Society's Press|language=en}} Present Worldwide Figures Unknown, but about 1.71 million in [[Hyderabad District, India|Hyderabad district]]http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/c-01.html | popplace = {{flagcountry|India}} • {{flagcountry|Pakistan}} • {{flagcountry|Saudi Arabia}} • {{flagcountry|United Arab Emirates}} • {{flagcountry|United States of America}} • {{flagcountry|United Kingdom}} | languages = [[Urdu]] in the forms of [[Hyderabadi Urdu]] and the [[Dakhini]] sub-dialect as well as standard [[Urdu]]• [[Hindi language|Hindi]] • [[Telugu language|Telugu]] • [[Marathi language|Marathi]]• [[Kannada language|Kannada]]• [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] • [[English language|English]] • The vernacular languages of other countries in the diaspora | rels = •[[Islam]] • Majority [[Sunni]] • Minority [[Shia]] and [[Isma'ilism]] | related = • Other [[Indian Muslim]] communities • [[Telugu people]] • [[Andhra Muslims]] • [[Marathi Muslims]] • [[Dakhini Muslims]] • [[Muhajir people]] }} '''Hyderabadi Muslims''' are an [[Ethnoreligious group|ethnoreligious]] community of [[Dakhini| Dakhini Urdu]]-speaking [[Muslims]], part of a larger group of [[Dakhini Muslims]], from the area that used to be the [[Hyderabad State|princely state of Hyderabad]], India, including cities like [[Hyderabad]], [[Aurangabad, Maharashtra|Aurangabad]], [[Latur]], [[Gulbarga]] and [[Bidar]]. While the term "''Hyderabadi''" now only refers to residents in and around the city of [[Hyderabad]], the term Hyderabadi Muslims can refer to those native Muslim residents of the erstwhile princely state. The native language of the Hyderabadi Muslims is [[Hyderabadi Urdu]], which is a form of the [[Dakhini|Dakhini language]]. With their origins in the Muslim [[Bahmani Sultanate]] and then the [[Deccan sultanates]], [[Culture of Hyderabad|Hyderabadi Muslim culture]] became defined in the latter half of the reign of the [[Nizam|Asif Jahi Dynasty]] in Hyderabad. The culture exists today mainly in the [[Old City (Hyderabad, India)|old city of Hyderabad]], [[Aurangabad, Maharashtra|Aurangabad]], [[Bidar]] and among the Hyderabadi Muslim diaspora around the world, in particular, Pakistan,{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-01-07/hyderabad/30601526_1_hyderabadis-culture-deccani |title=Hyderabadis in Pakistan still carry mohajir tag: Karen Leonard – Times Of India |publisher=The Times of India |date=7 January 2012 |accessdate=2012-04-30}} the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]], USA, Canada and the United Kingdom.{{cite news| title=The Muslim question| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-11/hyderabad/30386295_1_muslim-masses-telangana-telugu-culture| publisher=articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com| date=11 November 2011| accessdate=16 April 2012}} {{Islam in India}} ==History== {{main|History of Hyderabad|Indian integration of Hyderabad}} The [[Deccan plateau]] acted as a bulwark sheltering [[South India]] from the invasions and political turmoil that affected North India. This allowed the Muslim-ruled state of Hyderabad to develop a distinctive culture during the [[Qutb Shahi dynasty]], brief [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] rule and later the [[Asaf Jahi dynasty|Asaf Jahi]] dynasty of the [[Nizam]]s. According to ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', the [[Osman Ali Khan|seventh Nizam]] was the richest man in the world during the late 1940s, and fifth richest person of all time according to Forbes Magazine after adjustment for inflation and currency purchasing power parity.{{Cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19370222,00.html|title=TIME Magazine Cover: The Nizam of Hyderabad - Feb. 22, 1937|website=TIME.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-08-03}} The [[Nizam]] was the Muslim ruler of the vast princely Hyderabad State. The capital city of [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] was primarily Urdu-speaking Muslim until the [[Hyderabad Campaign (1948)|Incorporation of Hyderabad into India]] and the subsequent rise to dominance of Telugu-speaking people of [[Telangana|Telangana State]]. The state's economy was agrarian, and Hyderabad was primarily a government and administrative hub, run mostly (but far from exclusively) by Muslims. The aristocracy, ''[[jagirdar]]s'' and ''[[deshmukh]]s'' (wealthy landowners), and even minor government officials, could afford to hire servants, usually also Muslims, in a social order similar to the class system of [[Victorian era|Victorian England]]. The Nizam allied himself with the British early on, with ensuing political stability. The Muslim upper and middle classes were free to concentrate on a care-free and leisurely lifestyle involving clothes, jewelry, food, music, literary arts, and other indulgences, little of which trickled down to the servant class, known as ''naukar'' (a word originally used for the Mughal Emperor [[Babur]]'s closest feudal retainers). After the fall of the [[Mughal Empire]] in [[Indian Rebellion of 1857|1857]], many Muslim writers, poets, scholars, musicians and other eminent personalities migrated from [[Delhi]] to [[Hyderabad]] in hope of seeking patronage of the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam]] or the nobility. Muslims continued to emigrate to the state seeking employment in the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam's]] court, army, [[Hyderabad Civil Service]] or educational institutions. Among those who spent significant time in Hyderabad are writers [[Dagh Dehlvi]], [[Fani Badayuni]], [[Josh Malihabadi]], [[Ali Haider Tabatabai]], religious scholar [[Shibli Nomani|Shilbi Nomani]] and classical musicians [[Tanrus Khan]] and [[Bade Ghulam Ali Khan]]. After [[Independence Day (India)|Indian Independence]] from the [[British Raj]], [[Hyderabad State]], under the rule of the [[Osman Ali Khan, Asaf Jah VII|seventh Nizam]] lasted for a year, until September 18, 1948, when the Indian Army launched [[Indian integration of Hyderabad|Operation Polo]], and invaded Hyderabad state, annexing it into the [[Dominion of India|Indian Union]]. The Invasion resulted in the massacre of thousands of Hyderabadi Muslims, and mass migration mainly to the west, and [[Pakistan]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FzyKngEACAAJ|title=The Destruction of Hyderabad|last=Noorani|first=A. G.|date=2014-01-01|publisher=Hurst|isbn=9781849044394|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M0ovAAAAMAAJ|title=Hyderabad, after the fall|last=Khalidi|first=Omar|last2=Society|first2=Hyderabad Historical|date=1988-01-01|publisher=Hyderabad Historical Society|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HQCvgavbQjgC|title=Locating Home: India's Hyderabadis Abroad|last=Leonard|first=Karen Isaksen|date=2007-01-01|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=|isbn=9780804754422|location=|pages=32|language=en}} ===Hyderabadi Muslim Identity after Integration === [[File:Hyderabad State reorganization 1956.png|thumb|Hyderabad State Divided Amongst Three New Indian States]] The [[Indian integration of Hyderabad|Integration of Hyderabad]], into the [[dominion of India]], other than the shock of the controversial massacre of the integration,{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M0ovAAAAMAAJ|title=Hyderabad, after the fall|last=Khalidi|first=Omar|last2=Society|first2=Hyderabad Historical|date=1988-01-01|publisher=Hyderabad Historical Society|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-24159594|title=Hyderabad 1948: India's hidden massacre - BBC News|website=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-03-20}} took a turn of an identity crisis for the Hyderabadi Muslim people.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HQCvgavbQjgC|title=Locating Home: India's Hyderabadis Abroad|last=Leonard|first=Karen Isaksen|date=2007-01-01|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=9780804754422|language=en}} Thousands of Hyderabadi Muslims emigrated from the newly integrated Indian [[Hyderabad State (1948–56)|state of Hyderabad]] to Pakistan, the UK, the U.S. and Canada, resulting in a large diaspora.{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/The-Muslim-question/articleshow/10695169.cms|title=The Muslim question - Times of India|website=The Times of India|access-date=2016-03-20}} The people who migrated to [[Pakistan]] were now placed under a new term called [[Muhajir people|Muhajir]], along with other Urdu speaking immigrants from present day [[India]]. The Muhajir people began to dominate politics and business mainly in the metropolitan city of [[Karachi]] but their unique Hyderabadi Muslim Identity was lost, and has now evolved into a result of Karachi's booming cosmopolitan scene.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1082152|title=The Mohajir question|last=Murtaza|first=Dr Niaz|date=2014-01-23|website=www.dawn.com|access-date=2016-03-20}} The Hyderabadi Muslims who stayed in the integrated [[Hyderabad State (1948–56)|Hyderabad state]] were faced with new language issues, and a wave of immigration from other Indian states, especially after 1956.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Av89AAAAYAAJ|title=Agricultural Development in Hyderabad State, 1900-1956: A Study in Economic History|date=1882-01-01|publisher=Keshav Prakashan|language=en}} After the [[States Reorganisation Act, 1956|Indian reorganization of 1956]], with states being divided on linguistic lines, Hyderabadi Muslims, in [[Telangana]], [[Marathwada]], and [[Hyderabad-Karnataka]] were faced with the learning and emerging dominance of Telugu, Marathi, and Kannada respectively, and their native language [[Dakhini]] became a home language while [[Urdu]] in the forefront of Politics in these regions became comparatively less widespread.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UHJtAAAAMAAJ|title=Journal of South Asian and Middle Eastern Studies|date=2003-01-01|publisher=Published under the auspices of the Pakistan American Foundation|language=en}} The present day Hyderabadi Muslims know very little about their cultural heritage, especially those who aren't from Hyderabad city, or India. Hyderabadi Muslims are now seen as a result of Indian cosmopolitanism, and their history is being lost in Indian textbooks.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-UjZlNCh-qwC&pg=PA59&dq=Indian+Cosmopolitanism,+Hyderabad&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiL4anCrc7LAhXkuIMKHbk9DawQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=Indian%2520Cosmopolitanism%252C%2520Hyderabad&f=false|title=Making India: Colonialism, National Culture, and the Afterlife of Indian English Authority|last=Paranjape|first=Makarand R.|date=2012-09-03|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9789400746619|language=en}} The relative isolation of Hyderabad until [[Hyderabad Campaign (1948)|annexation to India]], its distinctive dialect of Urdu and the strong web of interconnecting family relationships that still characterizes Hyderabadi Muslims, sometimes leads to charges of parochialism from other Indian Muslim communities, but it also ensures a Hyderabadi Muslim identity endures among the Indian diaspora. ==Demographics and distribution== [[File:Charminar Karachi.JPG|thumb|left|180px|A replica of the [[Charminar]] built by Hyderabadi Muslims in [[Bahadurabad]], Karachi, Pakistan]] The largest concentration of Hyderabadi Muslims is in the [[Old City (Hyderabad, India)|old city of Hyderabad]]. After the [[Partition of India]] and the [[Operation Polo|Incorporation of Hyderabad by India]], the Muslims of the state lost their privileged status, so significant numbers chose to migrate to other countries such as [[Pakistan]], the [[Arab States of the Persian Gulf]], the [[United States]], [[UK]], [[Canada]] and [[Australia]].[[#Leonard07|Leonard 2007]][[#Leonard09|Leonard 2009]] A section of Hyderabadi Muslims are of [[Hadhrami people|Hadhrami]] Arab origin, who came to serve in the Nizam's military. They are known as [[Chaush]] and mostly reside in the [[Barkas, Hyderabad|Barkas]] neighbourhood of Hyderabad. There are also some [[Siddi]]s who are of African descent.[[#Yimene04|Yimene 2004]][[#Ali96|Ali 1996]]: 193–202 In [[Pakistan]], most of the Hyderabadi migrants are settled in the southern port city of [[Karachi]]. Estimates of the Hyderabadi population in Karachi range between 20,000 and 200,000 today.[[#Leonard03|Leonard2003]]: 232 The main neighbourhoods where the Hyderabadi migrants in Karachi initially settled were [[Hyderabad Colony]], [[Bahadurabad]] and [[Laiqabad]].[[#Ansari05|Ansari 2005]]: 140 In 2007, a replica of the famous [[Charminar]] monument in Hyderabad was built at the main crossing of [[Bahadurabad]].{{cite news|last=Zakaria|first=M. Rafique|title=Charminar in Karachi|url=http://news.dawn.com/weekly/dmag/archive/070422/dmag3.htm|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120723012359/http://news.dawn.com/weekly/dmag/archive/070422/dmag3.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 July 2012|newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=22 April 2007}} Some notable [[Pakistani]] people who migrated from the former [[Hyderabad State]] include [[Muhammad Raziuddin Siddiqui]], [[Syed Mohammad Ahsan]], [[Asif Iqbal Razvi]], [[Waheed Yar Khan]], and [[Anwar Maqsood]]. === Classification === [[File:Jummat-ul-wida.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Muslims offer Friday Prayers at [[Mecca Masjid]]]] Hyderabadi Muslims today, refer to the Urdu speaking Muslim community, from the 1801 landlocked [[Hyderabad State|princely state of Hyderabad]], who developed a distinct cultural identity from other [[Dakhini Muslims]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RAON5AW4yUEC|title=A Comprehensive History of India|date=2003-12-01|publisher=Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd|isbn=9788120725065|language=en}} Even though the princely state of Hyderabad had once reached the southernmost points of India, it's the culture from the known landlocked territories of the Nizam, that constitutes [[Culture of Hyderabad|Hyderabadi Muslim culture]], while the Dakhini Muslims of the [[Nawab of the Carnatic|Carnatic]], and the Circars, developed their own distinct culture, and culinary tradition.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eAEyAmYRNNQC|title=Political History of Carnatic Under the Nawabs|last=Ramaswami|first=N. S.|date=1984-01-01|publisher=Abhinav Publications|isbn=9780836412628|language=en}} The [[Chaush]] community, even though they speak Urdu, and live in the erstwhile Hyderabad State, are usually not considered Hyderabadi Muslims, since they came recently to the region. Even though they absorbed many Hyderabadi Muslim cultural features, namely language and cuisine (Chaush cuisine has more Arab influences), they're a more homogeneous group, of Hadhrami Arab ancestry, and reside in close knit Chaush communities such as the [[Barkas, Hyderabad|Barkas neighborhood]] of Hyderabad.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O_WNqSH4ByQC|title=Mediaeval Deccan History: Commemoration Volume in Honour of Purshottam Mahadeo Joshi|last=Kulakarṇī|first=A. Rā|date=1996-01-01|publisher=Popular Prakashan|isbn=9788171545797|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://shareefmp.wordpress.com/2010/03/05/barkas-a-small-yemen-in-hyderabad/|title=Barkas: A Small Yemen in Hyderabad|date=2010-03-05|website=Hyderabad Notes|access-date=2016-07-02}} This is compared to most Hyderabadi Muslims, who have ancestries from various ethnic origins, and are less a homogeneous group.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j2F9BgAAQBAJ|title=The Sufis of Bijapur, 1300-1700: Social Roles of Sufis in Medieval India|last=Eaton|first=Richard Maxwell|date=2015-03-08|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=9781400868155|language=en}} [[File:India1760 1905.jpg|thumb|[[Hyderabad Deccan]] (Green in the South) at its greatest extent]] ==Politics== Hyderabadi Muslims have organized themselves politically along religious lines.The most prominent example of this is the [[All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen]], currently led by [[Asaduddin Owaisi]]. The party dominates the politics in Hyderabad's [[Old City (Hyderabad, India)|Old City]], and consistently wins seats for the [[Lok Sabha]] (Lower House of Indian Parliament) and the [[Telangana Legislative Assembly]]. The party claims to represent the interests of Muslims by campaigning for greater protection of minority rights.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aimim.in/about-the-party/history/|title=History - All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen|website=All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160702085450/http://www.aimim.in/about-the-party/history/|archive-date=2 July 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} A rival breakaway faction of the AIMIM is the [[Majlis Bachao Tehreek]] that also claims to represent the interests of Muslims in Hyderabad. Hyderabadi Muslims who have been strong supporters of secular progressive movements, such as [[Indian Rebellion of 1857|Indian freedom fighters]] [[Maulvi Allauddin]], [[Turrebaz Khan]],{{Cite news|url=https://telanganatoday.com/turrebaz-khan-the-forgotten-hero|title=Turrebaz Khan: The forgotten hero|last=Gopal|first=M. Sai|date=|work=Telangana Today|access-date=}} [[Abid Hasan]], Urdu poets [[Makhdoom Mohiuddin]] and [[Sulaiman Areeb]], and [[Hassan Nasir]] who participated in the [[Telangana Rebellion]] against the rule of the [[Nizam]]. Hyderabadi Muslims were also at the forefront of the formation of the [[Comrades Association]] in 1939, one of the first communist organizations in Hyderabad which struggled against the [[Nizam]]. Other secular members of the community include Shoaibullah Khan, the editor of the Urdu daily ''Imroz'' that was critical of the [[Razakars (Hyderabad)|Razakars]] and urged Hyderabad's integration with India (he was stabbed to death). The story of a poor Muslim peasant named ''Bandagi'' who was killed while struggling against the landlord was immortalised in the popular drama [[Ma Bhoomi]] about the [[Telangana Rebellion]]. In 1946, editor of Urdu daily'' Saltanat'' [[Sayyid Ahmedullah Qadri]] was the first journalist of [[Hyderabad state]] who wrote articles on the One nation Theory. == Culture == {{Main|Culture of Hyderabad}} [[File:Hyderabad Mah Laqa Bhai 17710 600w.jpg|thumb|[[Mah Laqa Bai]]]] Hyderabadi Muslims, are noted for their hospitable nature also known as [[Culture of Hyderabad|Deccani Tehzeeb]]. While Hyderabadi Muslims take pride in their "Nawabi" language, literature, poetry, architecture, and cuisine. The performing arts are often overlooked, especially regarding Hyderabadi culture. In fact, the culture of the Hyderabadi Muslims is being lost.{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Deccani-tehzeeb-is-history/articleshow/11126520.cms?referral=PM|title=‘Deccani tehzeeb is history’ - The Times of India|website=The Times of India|access-date=2016-03-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.deccanchronicle.com/opinion/op-ed/181016/celebrating-a-long-gone-hyderabad.html|title=Celebrating a long gone Hyderabad|date=2016-10-18|work=Deccan Chronicle|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en}} The founding of the city of [[Hyderabad]] can be attributed to one of the wives of [[Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah]], [[Bhagmati|Queen Bhagyamati]], who was a dancer in the courts of the [[Qutb Shahi dynasty|Golkonda]] kings, with whom the founder of Hyderabad had named the city in her honour, ''Bhagyanagar'', and later Hyderabad. Tales of the legendary dancers Taramati, and Premamati, are also an insight into the rich culture under the [[Qutb Shahi dynasty|Qutb Shahi]] era. [[Mah Laqa Bai|Mah Laqa Bhai]], a prominent Hyderabadi Muslim poet of the 18th century, patronized the [[Kathak]] dance form in the courts of the Nizam, which is now being lost amongst Hyderabadi Muslims.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nizamabadnews.in/2014/05/18/center-deccan-studiesjournal-html/|title=Center for Deccan Studies|last=Desk|first=Nizamabad News Central|website=Nizamabad News నిజామాబాద్ న్యూస్|access-date=2016-03-18}} [[File:Taramati-Baradari.jpg|thumb|The legendary ''Taramati'' used to sing for travelers at the [[Taramati Baradari]]|alt=|left]] Apart from these, a traditional Hyderabadi Muslim wedding is identified by various local traditional elements, such as the traditional garb, [[Sherwani]] for the groom and [[Khara dupatta|Khada Dupatta]] along with jewelry for the bride, as well as [[Hyderabadi cuisine]] served at the ceremony. Another cultural practice unique to the region is ''[[Tasmia Qwani]]'' also known as ''Bismillah Ceremony'', family ceremony in which a Muslim child is initiated to read the [[Quran]]. It is also characterized by local elements.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/60333275|title=An African Indian community in Hyderabad : Siddi identity, its maintenance and change|last=Ababu.|first=Minda Yimene,|date=2004|publisher=Cuvillier|isbn=3865372066|edition=1. Aufl|location=Göttingen|oclc=60333275}} Communal Harmony, known as [[Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb|Ganga-Jamuni Tehzeeb]], is integral to the [[Culture of Hyderabad]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/telangana/kcr-vows-to-get-ganga-jamuni-tehzeeb-back/article7416305.ece|title=KCR vows to get ‘Ganga Jamuni tehzeeb’ back|date=2015-07-13|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-08-03|others=Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Muslims-keep-alive-spirit-of-Ganga-Jamuni-tehzeeb/articleshow/49164464.cms|title=Muslims keep alive spirit of Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-08-03}}{{Cite web|url=https://archive.siasat.com/news/ganga-jamuni-tehzeeb-temple-serving-iftar-dates-to-5-mosques-in-hyderabad-779534/|title=Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb: Temple serving Iftar Dates to 5 Mosques in Hyderabad {{!}} The Siasat Daily|website=archive.siasat.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-03}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.india-seminar.com/2008/585/585_bilkees_i_latif.htm|title=585 Bilkees I. Latif, The soul of Hyderabad|website=www.india-seminar.com|access-date=2018-08-08}} Other than musical forms of art, Hyderabadi Muslims have taken great honour in the writing, and reading of poetry, and annual [[Mushaira]]s and [[Mehfil]]s take place around the world, which has become a symbol of unity for Hyderabadi Muslims, and [[Urdu]] poets alike, continuing an ancient tradition.{{Cite web|url=http://twocircles.in/2012nov14/4th_annual_mehfilehyderabad_celebrated_mississauga.html|title=4th Annual Mehfil-e-Hyderabad Celebrated in Mississauga {{!}} TwoCircles.net|website=twocircles.in|access-date=2016-03-18}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Language and literature=== {{main|Hyderabadi Urdu|Dakhini}} [[File:Hyderabad City IB1142.jpg|thumb|Students at the [[Osmania University]], circa 1940's]] One of the most identifiable markers of Hyderabadi Muslim culture is the [[Hyderabadi Urdu|local dialect of Urdu]], called [[Hyderabadi Urdu]] which in itself is a form of [[Dakhini]]. It is distinct by its mixture of vocabulary from [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Persian language|Persian]] and [[Arabic]], as well in some vocabulary from [[Telugu language|Telugu]] and [[Marathi language|Marathi]] that are not found in the standard dialect of [[Urdu]]. In terms of pronunciation, the easiest way to recognize a Hyderabadi Urdu is use of "nakko"(no) and "hau"(yes); whereas in standard Urdu its "nahi" for (no) and "haa" for (yes). Though [[Hyderabadi Urdu]] or [[Dakhini]] are the native languages of the Hyderabadi Muslim people, most people can speak standard [[Urdu]], and often put Urdu as their mother tongue on censuses, as Dakhini is not a recognized language as such. Along with the languages they learn from birth, they can speak [[Hindi]], which is mutually ineligible with standard [[Urdu]], and taught in most Indian schools. Hyderabadi Muslims can also speak the majority languages spoken in the regions they live, namely [[Telugu language|Telugu]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], and [[Kannada]]. The other important characteristic of the natives is cultural refinement in terms of interpersonal communication, referred to as ''meethi boli'' (sweet and civilised speech). ''Tameez'', ''tehzeeb'' and ''akhlaq'' (etiquette, custom, and tradition) are considered very important and guests are treated well with a lot of ''mehmaan nawaazi'' (hospitality). The [[Qutb Shahi dynasty|Qutb Shahs]] were regarded as the great patrons of [[Urdu]], [[Farsi]] and [[Telugu language|Telugu]] language. The region saw a growth of [[Deccani Urdu]] literature, the ''[[Deccani Masnavi]]'' and ''[[Diwan (poetry)|Diwan]]'' composed during those periods are among the earliest available manuscripts in the Urdu language. The literary work of this region is influenced with the regional [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Telugu language|Telugu]], and [[Kannada language|Kannada]] in parallel with [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[Persian language|Persian]] including the adoption of poetic meters and a great quantity of renovated words.{{cite book|title=Mohammad Quli Qutb Shah, volume 216|publisher=[[Sahitya Akademi]]|pages=50–77|year=1996|isbn=978-81-260-0233-7 |last=Hussain Khan|first=Masud}} The Fifth Sultan of the dynasty, [[Mohammed Quli Qutb Shah]] was himself an [[List of Urdu poets|Urdu poet]].{{Cite web|url=https://archive.siasat.com/news/quli-qutub-shah-remembered-his-400th-death-anniversary-244924/|title=Quli Qutub Shah remembered on his 400th death anniversary {{!}} The Siasat Daily|website=archive.siasat.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-08}} The period of [[Asaf Jahi Dynasty|Nizams]] saw a growth of literary growth since after printing was introduced in Hyderabad. In 1824 AD, the first collection of Urdu ''[[Ghazal]]s'' named ''Gulzar-e-Mahlaqa'' (Mahlaqa's garden of flowers) written by [[Mah Laqa Bai]], was printed and published from Hyderabad.{{cite book|title=Women writing in India volume 1, 600 BC to the Early Twentieth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u297RJP9gvwC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=[[The Feminist Press]]|page=120|year=1991|isbn=978-1-55861-027-9 |last1=Susie|first1=Tharu|last2=K|first2=Lalita|accessdate=23 June 2012}} After the [[Revolt of 1857]], many Urdu writers, scholars and poets who lost their patronage at [[Delhi]] made Hyderabad their home, that grew and brought reforms in the literary and poetry work. Scholars continued to migrate to Hyderabad during the reign of [[Asaf Jah VI]] and his successor [[Asaf Jah VII]]. These included [[Shibli Nomani]], [[Dagh Dehlvi]], [[Fani Badayuni]], [[Josh Malihabadi]], [[Ali Haider Tabatabai]], Zahir Dehlvi and many others.{{cite book|title=Encyclopaedia of Indian literature: Devraj to Jyoti, Volume 2|publisher=[[Sahitya Akademi]]|pages=1260, 1746–1748|year=2005|isbn=978-81-260-1194-0 |last=Datta|first=Amaresh}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2018/mar/31/city-of-bards-eminent-poets-who-settled-down-in-hyderabad-1794858.html|title=City of Bards: Eminent poets who settled down in Hyderabad|work=The New Indian Express|access-date=2018-08-08}} The reign of [[Mir Osman Ali Khan|Nizam VII]] saw many reforms in literary work. For the first time in history the [[Nizams]] introduced [[Urdu]] as a language of court, administration and education. Other notable poets, scholars and writers of the early 20th century are [[Amjad Hyderabadi]],{{Cite web|url=https://archive.siasat.com/news/hyderabad-observe-104th-anniversary-musi-flood-349446/|title=Hyderabad to observe 104th anniversary of Musi flood {{!}} The Siasat Daily|website=archive.siasat.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-22}} [[Makhdoom Mohiuddin]], [[Sayyid Shamsullah Qadri]], [[Mohiuddin Qadri Zore]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.prlog.org/11428536-syed-mohiuddin-qadri-zore-ma-phd.html|title=Syed Mohiuddin Qadri, 'Zore'- MA, PhD.|last=Forum|first=Pak-American International|website=PRLog|access-date=2018-07-22}} and [[Sulaiman Areeb]]. [[Maharaja Sir Kishen Pershad]], although not a Muslim himself, was steeped in Hyderabadi Muslim Culture and wrote poetry under the pen name ''Shad''.{{cite newspaper|title=Sir Kishen Pershad Passes Away|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=168-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=AkwMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6865%2C1236175|accessdate=8 February 2018|work=The Indian Express|date=14 May 1940|page=2}} In 2017, [[Urdu]] was declared the second official language of the state of [[Telangana]]. (after [[Telugu language|Telugu]]) This move was praised by many, especially Muslims of Hyderabad who spoke [[Urdu]] as their mother tongue.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/urdu-second-official-language-telangana-state-passes-bill-71742|title=Urdu is second official language in Telangana as state passes Bill|date=2017-11-17|work=The News Minute|access-date=2018-07-22}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/urdu-is-second-official-language-now/article20493655.ece|title=Urdu is second official language now|date=2017-11-17|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-07-22|others=Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} === Music === Though, the once great dance traditions among the Hyderabadi Muslims are almost lost, two distinct, cultural practices are still popular, namely [[Marfa (music)|Marfa]], and Dholak ke Geet. [[Marfa (music)|Marfa]] was brought by the [[Siddi]] and [[Chaush]] peoples, of [[Africa]] and [[Yemen]], who were deployed in the army of the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizams]]. This music, is accompanied by the beating drums of a great tradition, which were once popular in national celebrations of the dissolved [[Hyderabad State|Hyderabad state]], is still popular among Hyderabadi Muslims in weddings.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/article2216021.ece#|title=‘Marfa' band of the Siddis ‘losing' its beat|date=2011-07-10|newspaper=The Hindu|access-date=2016-03-18|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} ''Dholak ke geet'' is also one such great tradition. ''Dholak ke geet'' are songs, that have been orally passed down from generation to generation since the time of the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizams]], and is sung at weddings, accompanied by a [[Dholak]] drum.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8830KZLvkYsC|title=Deccan Heritage|last=Gupta|first=Harsh K.|date=2000-01-01|publisher=Universities Press|isbn=9788173712852|language=en}} ''[[Qawwali]]'' is also popular among the community,{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefridaytimes.com/31122010/page29.shtml|title=A song of Hyderabad|last=Khan|first=Bilquis Jehan|date=|website=www.thefridaytimes.com|access-date=2018-08-11}} and is performed regularly at [[Dargah|''dargahs'']] such as [[Dargah Yousufain]] and [[Pahadi Shareef|Dargah Pahadi Shareef]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.natgeotraveller.in/hyderabad-guide-nizami-opulence-chic-cafes-and-qawwali-performances/|title=Hyderabad Guide: Nizami Opulence, Chic Cafes, and Qawwali Performances|work=Your Site NAME Goes HERE|access-date=2018-08-11}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/special-place-for-qawwali-in-hyderabad/article3271428.ece|title=Special place for qawwali in Hyderabad|last=Farida|first=Syeda|date=2012-04-02|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-08-11|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} It used to be patronized by the [[Nizam|Nizams]] as well as the nobility. The great classical musicians such as [[Bade Ghulam Ali Khan]], [[Inayat Khan]], [[Tanrus Khan|Ustad Tanrus Khan]], [[Munshi Raziuddin]] and [[Qawwal Bahauddin Khan|Bahauddin Khan]] used to perform at the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam's]] court. The contemporary [[Qawwali|''qawwals'']] [[Ateeq Hussain Khan]] and the [[Warsi Brothers]] reside in [[Hyderabad]] and perform regularly in the city. ===Cuisine=== {{main|Hyderabadi cuisine}} [[File:Chicken Hyderabadi Biryani.JPG|thumb|[[Hyderabadi biryani|Hyderabadi Biryani]]]] [[File:Haleem hyderabadi.jpg|thumb|[[Hyderabadi Haleem]]]] The native cooking style of the community is the [[Hyderabadi cuisine]], which evolved during the [[Asaf Jahi dynasty|Asaf Jahi]] period. It is heavily influenced by [[Mughlai cuisine|Mughal]], [[Turkish cuisine|Turkish]], and [[Arabic cuisine|Arab]] along with the influence of the native [[Telugu cuisine|Telugu]] and [[Marathwada]] cuisines. It comprises a broad repertoire of rice, wheat and meat dishes and the skilled use of various spices, herbs and natural edibles.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pFivPqq7FbIC&|title=Royal Hyderabadi Cooking|last=Kapoor|first=Sanjeev|publisher=[[Popular Prakashan]]|year=2008|isbn=978-81-7991-373-4|accessdate=19 September 2011}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HQCvgavbQjgC&|title=Locating home: India's Hyderabadis abroad|last=Leonard|first=Karen Isaksen|publisher=stanford university press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-8047-5442-2|accessdate=19 September 2011}} Some famous [[Hyderabadi cuisine]] (dishes) that are served at weddings are: [[Hyderabadi Biryani]], [[Hyderabadi Haleem|Haleem]], [[Khubani ka Mitha]], [[Gil-e-Firdaus]], [[Double Ka Meetha]], [[Luqmi]], Kaddu ki Kheer (A type of [[Kheer]]), [[Mirchi ka Salan]] and [[Baghare Baigan]]. Other popular food items are: [[Chakna]], [[Tamate ka Kut]], [[Khatti Dal]], [[Dalcha]], [[Shirmal]], Rawghani Roti, [[Nahari]], Pasande, [[Pathar-ka-Gosht|Pathar Ka Ghosht]], [[Naan]], Dum Ka Murgh, [[Khagina]], [[Khichdi]], Nargisi Kheema, Shaami, Kofte, Tala Hua Ghosht, Poori, Kheer, [[Sheer Khorma]], Til ka Khatta, Til ki Chutney and Qubuli, Shikampur, Tahari, [[Khichdi]]. The Arab dishes [[Mandi (food)|Mandi]] and [[Shawarma]] are also popular. The dishes are tied to events, such as [[Hyderabadi Haleem]], made almost exclusively during the month of [[Ramadan]],{{Cite news|url=https://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/10/hyderabads-charm-found-in-ramadan-delights/|title=Hyderabad's Charm Found in Ramadan Delights|last=Alluri|first=Aparna|work=India Ink|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}} and [[Sheer Khorma]] which is especially made on the day of [[Eid al-Fitr|Eid-ul-Fitr]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/Hyderabad-says-Eid-Mubarak/article14476732.ece|title=Hyderabad says Eid Mubarak|date=2016-07-08|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-07-22|others=Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}{{Cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/food-recipes/ramadan-special-recipe-sheer-khurma-watch-here-1063802.htm|title=Ramadan special recipe: Sheer Khurma—Watch here!|date=2014-07-25|work=Zee News|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}} [[Tala huwa gosht|Talawa Gosht]] is prepared on Fridays. [[Irani café|Irani Chai]] is enjoyed throughout the city, along with [[Osmania Biscuit]]s. [[Irani café|Irani Cafes]] found all over Hyderabad serve these along with [[Lukhmi]], [[Samosa]] and other snacks.{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/travel/eating-out/irani-chai-taste-of-persia-in-hyderabad/as32651993.cms|title=Irani Chai: Taste of Persia in Hyderabad|work=Times of India Travel|access-date=2018-07-22}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/life-and-style/food/hotel-shadab-is-a-transit-eatery-for-those-heading-towards-charminar-and-old-city/article19103252.ece|title=The chai destination in Old City|last=Nayak|first=Ashis|date=2017-06-19|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} ===Clothing and jewellery=== ====''Khada Dupatta''==== {{Main|Khara dupatta}} The ''Khada Dupatta'' or ''[[Khara Dupatta]]'' (uncut veil) is an outfit composed of a ''kurta'' (tunic), ''[[chooridaar]]'' (ruched pair of pants), and 6 yard ''dupatta'' (veil) and is traditionally worn by Hyderabad brides. Sometimes the ''kurta'' is sleeveless and worn over a ''koti'' resembling a [[choli]]. The bride also wears a matching ''ghoonghat'' (veil) over her head. The accompanying jewellery is:{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/235042642|title=The untold Charminar : writings on Hyderabad|date=2008|publisher=Penguin Books|others=Imam, Syeda.|isbn=9780143103707|location=New Delhi|oclc=235042642}} *''Tika'' (a medallion of uncut diamonds worn on the forehead and suspended by a string of pearls) *''Jhoomar'' (a fan shaped ornament worn on the side of the head) *''Nath'' (a nose ring with a large ruby bead flanked by two pearls) *''Chintaak'' also known as Jadaoo Zevar (a choker studded with uncut diamonds and precious stones) *''Kan phool'' (earrings that match the ''Chintaak'' and consist of a flower motif covering the ear lobe and a bell shaped ornament that is suspended from the flower. The weight of precious stones and gold in the ''Karan phool'' is held up by ''sahare'' or supports made of strands of pearls that are fastened into the wearers hair.) *''[[Satlada]]'' (neck ornament of seven strands of pearls set with emeralds, diamonds and rubies) *''Ranihaar'' (neck ornament of pearls with a wide pendant) *''Jugni'' (neck ornament of several strands of pearls with a central pendant) *''Gote'' (Shellac bangles studded with rhinestones and worn with gold coloured glass bangles called ''sonabai'') *''Payal'' (ankle bracelets) *''Gintiyan'' (toe rings)[[File:NizamViiMukarram.jpg|thumb|right|Asaf Jah VII with his grandson Mukarram Jah, both wearing a ''[[Sherwani]]'' and ''[[Rumi topi|Rumi Topi]]'']] ====''Sherwani''==== The ''[[Sherwani]]'' is the traditional men's garb of Hyderabad. It is a coat-like tunic with a tight-fitting collar (hook & eyelet fastening), close-fitting in the upper torso and flaring somewhat in its lower half. It usually has six or seven buttons, often removable ones made from gold sovereigns for special occasions. The material is usually silk or wool. A groom may use gold brocade for his wedding sherwani, but otherwise good taste dictates understated colors, albeit with rich and textured fabrics. The sherwani is usually worn over a silk or cotton ''kurta'' (long shirt) and ''pyjamas'' (baggy pants with a drawstring at the waist). The ''Sherwani'' is closely associated with Hyderabad, although it has spread since to the rest of India and to Pakistan. Former Prime Minister of India [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] adapted its design and turned it into his trademark ''[[Nehru Jacket]]'', further popularizing the garment. ====''Attar''==== [[Ittar|Attar]], or ''Ittar'' is a traditional perfume made from botanical sources. It is still available in the bazaars near [[Charminar]] and at the [[Moazzam Jahi Market|Moazam Jahi Market]]. Many of the older generations still prefer ''attar'' over modern [[perfume]]s.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/four-generations-later-art-ittar-losing-its-scent-hyderabad|title=Four generations later, the art of 'Ittar' is losing its scent in Hyderabad|date=2015-06-12|work=The News Minute|access-date=2018-07-22}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/tracing-the-fragrant-attar/article3707469.ece|title=Tracing the fragrant attar|last=Chakravorty|first=Sohini|date=2012-07-31|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/ittar-mingles-in-the-air-but-losing-aroma-among-youth/articleshow/62102671.cms|title=Ittar mingles in the air, but losing aroma among youth - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-07-22}}{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/The-new-scent-of-attar/articleshow/45396025.cms|title=The new scent of attar - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-07-22}} ==Religion== [[File:Mecca Masjid.1.jpg|thumb|The 400-year-old [[Mecca Masjid]] in [[Hyderabad]]]] The majority of Hyderabadi Muslims are [[Sunni]] and the two largest minorities are [[Shia]] and [[Mahdavia|Mahdavi]].{{cite news|title=Muslim society demonstrates diversity in its beliefs and practices|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Muslim-society-demonstrates-diversity-in-its-beliefs-and-practices/articleshow/53693572.cms|newspaper=Times of India|date=14 August 2016|accessdate=14 August 2016}} Sunni Muslims mostly follow the [[Hanafi]] school of [[Islamic Jurisprudence]], although the [[Chaush]] community follows the [[Shafi'i]] school of thought. Islam in Hyderabad, with historical patronizing by the rulers, has a strong Sufi influence. [[Tablighi Jamaat]] has also been active since late 1950's, with its headquarters at Jama Masjid Mallepally. [[Salafi movement|Salafis]], [[Dawoodi Bohra]] and [[Ismai'li]] are also in some areas. [[Bismillah ceremony]] is an Islam initiation ceremony held for children, unique to the region. [[Mourning of Muharram]] is observed by the [[Shia Islam|Shia]] community.{{Cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/news/india/no-parallel-to-hyderabads-muharram-procession-in-india-523357.html|title=No parallel to Hyderabad's Muharram procession in India|last=|first=|date=|work=News18|access-date=2018-08-21}} Processions are held every year, since the time of the [[Qutb Shahi dynasty]] as well as the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizams]]. Religious knowledge and its propagation flourished under the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam]] with institutions like the world-famous [[Jamia Nizamia]]. The largest Mosque of Hyderabad, the [[Makkah Masjid, Hyderabad|Makkah Masjid]] gathers congregations of more than two hundred thousand{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} on the occasions of [[Eid prayers]] and [[Jumu'atul-Wida|''Jumu'at-al Wida'']]. (the last Friday of [[Ramadan]]) Hyderabad has also produced many renowned religious scholars of representing different Islamic sects and trends, including [[Bahadur Yar Jung]], [[Muhammad Hamidullah]], [[Hashim Amir Ali]], [[Sayyid Shamsullah Qadri]], [[Sayyid Ahmedullah Qadri]], [[Abul Ala Maududi]] and [[M. A. {{Jehovah's Witnesses}}
[[Jehovah's Witnesses]] employ various levels of [[church discipline|congregational discipline]] as formal controls administered by congregation elders. Members who engage in conduct that is considered inappropriate may be counseled privately by elders and congregational responsibilities may be withheld or restricted. If initial counsel is not accepted, elders may present a talk to the congregation about the type of behavior, alerting other members already aware of the individual's conduct to limit social interaction with that person. Hearings involving "serious sin" are performed by formal ''judicial committees'', in which guilt and repentance are determined by a tribunal of elders. A variety of controls can be enforced, from ''reproof'' and restriction of congregational duties to [[excommunication]], known as ''disfellowshipping'', which includes [[shunning]] by the congregation. Individuals who are disfellowshipped may be reinstated after an extended period if they are deemed to demonstrate repentance. The practice of disfellowshipping has been criticized by many non-members and ex-members.
== Discipline involving non-judicial situations == At the elders' discretion, "non-judicial" situations may involve discipline of one or more of several types.
===Counsel=== ''Counsel'' may be given in situations involving actions that are considered inappropriate but are not considered to be of sufficient gravity to necessitate a judicial committee. Counsel may be provided by a mature Witness in addition to self-discipline and family discipline.<ref>{{cite book|title=Keep Yourselves in God's Love|publisher=Watch Tower Society|pages=142–143|url=http://wol.jw.org/en/wol/pl/r1/lp-e?q=lv%20142-143}}</ref> Elders may also give recommendations or warnings to members in non-judicial situations.
===Local needs=== At conventions and assemblies, and about once each month at a local [[Jehovah's Witnesses practices#Midweek meeting|midweek meeting]], a short talk regarding "local needs" is presented.<ref>''Our Kingdom Ministry'', Service meeting schedule, 1992-2009</ref> An elder addresses matters that are relevant to the local congregation, with instructions outlining the course of action considered appropriate. No specific individuals are identified during the talk, but the talk may relate to a matter for which a member has recently been "reproved". At times, some temporary policy may be announced that might be seen as disciplinary; for example, it may be that an additional attendant is assigned outside a [[Kingdom Hall]] to discourage children from running on the sidewalk.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Question Box|magazine=Our Kingdom Ministry|date=March 1972|page=4}}</ref>
===Shepherding calls=== Personal "shepherding visits" are intended to encourage members of the congregation, though may also include counsel and correction, then or on a subsequent visit.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Do You Accept Jehovah's Help?|magazine=The Watchtower|date=December 15, 2004|page=21|url=http://wol.jw.org/en/wol/d/r1/lp-e/2004924#h=23:393-27:438}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|title=Charisma—Praise to Man or Glory to God?|magazine=The Watchtower|date=February 15, 1998|page=27}}</ref> Two elders (or an elder and a ministerial servant) may schedule and perform a particular shepherding visit on their own or at the direction of the body of elders.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=How Christian Shepherds Serve You|magazine=The Watchtower|date=March 15, 1996|page=27}}</ref>
=== Withheld recommendations or assignments === The body of elders may withhold its recommendation for a member to serve in a new position of responsibility, though still permitting existing responsibilities.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Announcements|magazine=Our Kingdom Ministry|date=June 2005|page=3}}</ref>
For example, a ministerial servant who consistently seems insufficiently prepared for his meeting parts may have such assignments withheld for a time, even though he may continue serving as a ministerial servant or in some other "special privilege of service".{{Citation needed|reason=Old reference (to Ministry School book pg. 284) does not say anything in this regard|date=January 2017}}
=== Withheld "privileges" === An active Jehovah's Witness may have their congregational "privileges of service" limited, even without having committed a serious sin.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Let Discernment Safeguard You|magazine=The Watchtower|date=March 15, 1997|page=19|quote=Even well-meaning Christians have shared information about seemingly profitable ventures, only to find that they and those following their example lost the money they invested. As a result, a number of Christians have lost privileges in the congregation.}}</ref> While Witnesses sometimes refer to field ministry, after-meeting cleanup, and other responsibilities as "privileges", the term "privileges of service" often implies a specific range of assignments assisting elders and ministerial servants with meeting demonstrations and other responsibilities.{{Citation needed|reason=Old reference (to Ministry School book pg. 191) does not say anything in this regard|date=January 2017}} Such limitations are usually temporary.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Are You Reaching Out?|magazine=The Watchtower|date=September 1, 1990|page=23|quote=Even if counsel has been required, it may not be such a long time before a humble and grateful man again receives added privileges of service in the congregation.}}</ref>
Elders, ministerial servants, pioneers, or other appointed Witnesses can lose their "special privileges of service".<ref>Jehovah's Witnesses use the term "special privileges of service" for positions requiring formal appointment or approval, such as elder, ministerial servant, pioneer, Bethel (branch) service, and schools such as Gilead and Ministerial Training School; "Make Room for It", ''Our Kingdom Ministry'', April 2003, page 1</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Draw Close To Jehovah|pages=268–269|publisher=Watch Tower Society|url=http://wol.jw.org/en/wol/d/r1/lp-e/1102002051#h=28:0-30:0}}</ref> For example, an elder may be removed or choose to step aside voluntarily from his position if members of his household are not in "good standing".<ref>{{cite magazine|magazine=The Watchtower|date=October 15, 1996|page=21|title=Father and Elder—Fulfilling Both Roles}}</ref> After resignation or removal from an appointed position, an announcement is made during the congregation's Service Meeting indicating that the person is "no longer serving [in that capacity]", without elaboration.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Announcements|magazine=Our Kingdom Ministry|date=February 1991|page=7}}</ref>
=== Marking === Members who persist in a course considered scripturally wrong after repeated counsel by elders, but who are not considered guilty of something for which they could be disfellowshipped, can be "marked", based on Jehovah's Witnesses' interpretation of 2 Thessalonians 3:14.<ref name="wt041585">{{cite magazine|magazine=The Watchtower|date=April 15, 1985|page=31|title=Questions From Readers}}</ref> Actions for which an individual may be "marked" include [[dating]] a non-member,<ref>{{cite journal|journal=The Watchtower|date=July 15, 1999|page=31|title=Questions From Readers}}</ref> dating when not "scripturally" or legally free to marry,<ref>{{cite book|title=Shepherd the Flock of God|pages=124–5|publisher=Watch Tower Society}}</ref> being [[Laziness|lazy]], critical, or dirty, [[Busybody|meddling]], taking material advantage of others or indulging in "improper" entertainment.<ref>{{cite book|title=Organized to do Jehovah's will|pages=134–6|publisher=Watch Tower Society|year=2015|url=https://www.jw.org/en/publications/books/Organized-to-Do-Jehovahs-Will/|quote=This could include such things as being extremely lazy, critical, or dirty. He could be "meddling with what does not concern [him]." (2 Thess. 3:11) Or he might be one who schemes to take material advantage of others or indulges in entertainment that is clearly improper.}}</ref> "Marking" is indicated by means of a warning talk given to the congregation outlining the shameful course, without explicitly naming any particular individual. Members who know whose actions are being discussed may then consider the individual "marked". Though not shunned, "marked" individuals are looked upon as "bad association" and social interaction outside of formal worship settings is generally curtailed.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=The Watchtower|date=July 15, 1999|page=31|title=Questions From Readers|quote=Their ceasing to have social dealings and recreation with him might show him that principled people disliked his ways. ... Christians in the congregation who are thus alerted can individually decide to limit any socializing with ones who clearly are pursuing a disorderly course but who are still brothers.}}</ref> This action is intended to "shame" the person into following a particular course of action.<ref name="wt041585" />
== Discipline involving "serious sin" == If an active baptized Witness is considered to have committed a "serious sin" for which the individual must demonstrate formal repentance, correction (or, "discipline") is administered by the congregation's body of elders. Such situations usually involve a "judicial committee" of three or more elders.<ref name="org139">{{cite book|title=Organized to Do Jehovah's Will|year=2015|publisher=Watch Tower Society|page=139|url=https://www.jw.org/en/publications/books/Organized-to-Do-Jehovahs-Will/}}</ref>
